subject: Re: [junit] Stubbing with JUnit
msgSnippet: Also easymocks is pretty good if you want to mock interface. http://tammofreese.de/easymock/index.html -- Disclaimer:  I join all the news groups out of my own
messageBody:
Also easymocks is pretty good if you want to mock interface.


http://tammofreese.de/easymock/index.html

--
Disclaimer: I join all the news groups out of my own interest. All opinions expressed here are my own and not necessarily those of my employer.



Chris Eppstein wrote:

>please check out http://www.mockobjects.com/.
>
>chris eppstein
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: jan.rademakers@... [mailto:jan.rademakers@...]
>Sent: Wednesday, October 31, 2001 12:20 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [junit] Stubbing with JUnit
>
>
>
>
>
>Dear Sir/Mam,
>
>I am using JUnit under Netbeans because I was looking for a nice and easy
>way to
>test things.
>I really like the ability to create suites for regression testing etc.
>
>The only thing I cannot find out is the way of stubbing?
>Stubbing is when black box testing is done, and the class under test uses a
>sub-class. I want to create my own sub-class and controll the return values
>of
>that class. How can this be done and controlled from within the JUnit
>framework?
>The dumb way would be re-writing the sub-class myself with additional
>controlling methods, but I am looking for a more automatic and general
>approach.
>
>Can anyone help, or does anyone has any experience with stubs?
>
>Jan Rademakers
>jan.rademakers@...
>
>
>
>
